content: The Riemann integral can defined using Mathlib.Analysis.BoxIntegral.Basic and shown to exist for continuous functions using docs#BoxIntegral.integrable_of_continuousOn. However, there doesn't seem to be any result relating it to the Bochner integral since all the results in Mathlib.Analysis.BoxIntegral.Integrability have l.bRiemann = false as hypothesis. Is that correct?
I am interested in proving that the limit of the Riemann sums for some nonnegative continuous function is equal to the integral of the function.
Well, turns out it is easy to deduce the result from existing results for continuous functions, see #10144
